What you are describing is nothing new and frankly, inevitable in foreign policy.. After all, an enemy of my enemy is my friend.

Look at the Vietnamese and the Soviets during WW2. We aided and trained both to fight against the Japanese and the Germans. After a decade or so, they became our opponents.

The fact of the matter is simply this: Today's friend can no doubt become tomorrow's enemy. And there's nothing you can really do about it. People change and therefore countries change, when one nation's friend is no longer of use to them, they either become a threat or are treated indifferently.

I'm not saying it is right or fair, but it is what it is. The best we can do is hope to stay consistent in our foreign policy, to remember our friends and to constantly reinforce those friendships. This won't guarantee anything, but it decreases the likelihood of us making our own enemies.

Not just no interfering and no Kony - who cares one way or the other.
Shut down this idiotic Africa Command entirely and skip interfering on that continent completely. It's just none of their business what kind of governments they have over there in Africa. People who think they need to help out over there can just donate to some kind of charity like medcins sans frontiers or something. "Isolationism" for the US military and CIA, meaning a lack of their lousy interfering, is the right policy for the Evil Empire. Amerika is not the world's police force because Amerika stinks.

The most important sentence in this story is this one:

"And small groups of American advisers have been training African armies for years, though it is not always clear how well this turns out. Just a few weeks ago, Mali’s democratic government was ousted in a coup led by none other than an American-trained army captain."

US intervention in other countries always--always--has unintended consequences. Training Malian troops led to the overthrow of a democratic government. Supporting mujadaheen fighters against the Soviets led to the rise of Al Qaeda and 9/11 and endless wars in Afghanistan and then Iraq. What will be the blowback from supporting the Ugandan government's pursuit of Kony?

By raising this question, I'm not arguing for isolationism. The US is and must be involved in the world, and perhaps there's a way of helping in the search for Joseph Kony that can avoid such consequences. But if it's done without thinking through these questions, precedent teaches us that the results will be--first for Africans and later for Americans--disasters even worse than anything Kony himself has perpetrated.

Actually, that's unlikely.  It has far more to do with the continued stability of the Ugandan government and its supportive military relationship with the United States, critical in keeping down the Islamic fundamentalist al-Shabab group in Somalia.  Uganda has paid in blood and mayhem for its support of efforts to stabilize Somalia.  Sending in a hundred trained advisors is the least we can do.

Anything is possible, but as this diagram suggests,

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Uganda_Export_Treemap.png

petroleum of all types is a pretty small part of Ugandan exports (3.9%). Outranking oil are:

-"Cement clinkers" (4.0%)
-"Tobacco, unmanufactured" (5.1%)
-"Fish fillet or meat, not liver or roe" (6.5%)
-"Coffee, not roasted" (19.0%)

I remember the old sarcastic slogan "Would we have invaded Iraq if its primary export was brussels sprouts?" Is the next slogan "would we send the green berets to Uganda if its primary exports are coffee, tobacco, and 'clinkers'"? Apparently, the answer is yes.

The decision to send special forces to Africa was made public long before the viral video emerged. Remember many months ago when Limbaugh made a fool of himself by criticizing Obama because the "Lord's Resistance army" were supposedly Christian?

The article summed up the situation quite well, including the variety of reasons for intervention, as well as the role played by the Kony video. As far as Americans not understanding the reasons for our involvement, the article helps to address that.

I find the U.S. role very appropriate, and the article was good for background to understand that. Despite your innuendo, there's not much more to it.
Feel free to check out http://www.lracrisistracker.com/ for up-to-date info on the movement and actions of the LRA. It is information from sources in the heart of Central Africa.
Does that justify having gone after Saddam Hussein?

Funny that you seem to know everything about this "complicated story" after just "two minutes of web looking". You need to get a few of your facts straight.

This is no longer a civil war. The LRA was pushed out of Uganda years ago. Kony has virtually zero popular support there or anywhere else. The conflict with Kony and the LRA these days is really not that complicated. This is about hunting down a mass murderer and child abuser who is preying on vulnerable people in very isolated communities.

Kony has been doing this for far too long. Many other approaches have been tried and failed. It's about time the U.S finally put boots on the ground to help take him out. The fact that the U.S has a sizable special forces contingent on the hunt is pretty recent and significant news.

About two years ago I wrote a ~25 page position paper on the LRA's trail of terror and the various ideas/attempts to resolve it and have been following the conflict since then so I'm pretty well versed on the issue.

It would be silly to publish every detail of the story in a single article. Instead, the NYT chooses to publish different articles about the same topic. To me, this seems reasonable.

For example: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/20/world/africa/uganda-after-kony-2012-tr...

Or you could spend two seconds searching Kony in the nytimes search bar...
http://query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch/#/KONY/

Enjoy.

Of course in addition, the US is trying to find Kony not because he is a mass murderer, but because he is an enemy of a dictator we support.

The "much-hyped" Joseph Kony story? The man has left a trail of butchery and carnage across Central Africa. He's abducted thousands of children to serve as  killing machines in his personal army..He's wanted by the Hague for crimes against humanity. Yes, the region is riven with conflict, of which Kony is but one piece of the bloody mosaic, still, that we should consider reports of Kony's death squads mowing down rural villages as "hype" suggests a rather cynical, if not insular,  complacency.  Hype is a term reserved to describe the innocuous excesses of commerce, celebrity  and tabloidism. We here in the West may have an appetite for morbid sensationalism, but that hardly gives us permission to confuse Kony's grotesque, inhuman exploits with a tabloid headline.

Compulsory free public education began around the early 20th century, a time not so far away, when the grandparents of many of us were living. The whole society and economy spiraled upward due to free, good quality education. The mass middle class got started as a result. Low cost college came later.

Did we already reach the apex of this beneficial trend? Are we now seeing a backward slide toward unsupported public ed, mediocre standards, under funded schools? Segregation of rich and average in income? If so we will see an increase of ignorance, lack of general culture, and lack of information needed for political involvement in a democracy. This makes us ripe for even more corporate takeover of our society, well under way. And even in our schools.

Our dumbed down entertainment culture, and TV news infotainment works right in with this negative spiral backwards. The typical American of the future will be an obese person, walking along totally focused in their ipod, completely a captive of consumer advertising, corporate public relations, and political manipulation. This actually is already the case, as shown by the charade of our gop candidates ‘debates’ which were totally manufactured, stage-managed and manipulative, with little connection to reality.

The cut in higher education in California mentioned in the comment above is 400 million. That's one or two Hollywood block buster movies. It also represents the cost of only a few advanced weapon systems, like new fighter planes. Something is out of whack.

Now the scapegoat is population growth!  And shall we try a "one child policy" to solve this problem?

This is one of Krugman's essays with which I fully agree. Too bad Krugman doesn't note the real reason behind the high cost of a university education.

Yes states like California have been cutting back on higher education. The California governor is a Democrat, yet his budget for fiscal year 2012-13 calls for an INCREASE in spending on K12 education from $34.2 billion to $38.2 billion, up 11.8%, while it also calls for a DECREASE in spending on higher education from $9.8 billion to $9.4 billion, down 4.5%.

Why the difference? Well, California's population continues to grow and the number of children in K-12 schools is exploding. It would be unconscionable to not provide a basic education for all of these children. But the state simply does not have the funds to also pay for higher education for the exploding population.

In other words, because of population growth, California is educating more students for the lower paying unskilled and semi-skilled jobs, and fewer engineers and physicians.

Yet because of political correctness, population growth is a taboo topic, unmentionable as the potential source of America's economic problems.

Population growth affects all aspects of the economy, and America has not been able to provide jobs for all of the 60 million new people the US acquired over the last two decades. Population growth cannot be continued forever, and at some point it inexorably leads to economic problems such as those now confronting the US.

This is a specious argument from the start. Banks did not charge fees for checking accounts until recently. the primary means for banks to generate income was through savings and the float on deposits. they paid you a small percentage interest on savings accounts, and loaned that money out at twice the interest the interest rate they paid on your deposits. They seemed to do just fine in the world of economics. The commercial banks were the ones that loaned the money for local merchants to borrow for business expansion, or to buy homes.

Credit was usually through companies or people that you did business with. Credit cards were a thing of the future until the 1960s. Before that time you established credit with the local furniture store, or clothing store, and usually did not pay interest.

Then me the credit card which charged you interest and also charges the merchant woo accepted it a fee. This allowed the banks to give you instant credit and of course collect the interest, and fees. It also freed up employees in the loan department to concentrate on the better paying loans.

The came the ATM, an all of a sudden the banks decided to charge you for using them, even though it freed up tellers for other jobs. The banks knew a sucker when they saw one.

There were commercial banks and investment banks. The commercial banks made income form the float and interest on your loans. The investment banks financed corporate bonds and commercial expansion, they took more risks.

Wrong, Brian. How do you think people were able to become educated after WWII and begin one of the longest and greatest periods of economic growth the world has ever seen?

The GI Bill. Stafford Loans. Pell Grants. These are all government funded educational financing programs that allowed America to get where it is today.

Its that private bankers are already gauging students at 25% interest rates on student loans for all kinds of degrees, ultimately preventing them from ever being able to pay off such loans. Where have you been?

You offer no solution to the problem either. What would you suggest? Not have kids attend college and have an uneducated, uncreative society just because college is too expensive? That's too shortsighted.

Why not give discounts on loans to certain kinds of degree programs or a scholarship program set up for students with good grades from the country's biggest corporations: Amazon, Google, Apple, Facebook, IBM, GE, etc?

Criticize the status quo all you want, but at least try and offer some kind of a solution if you're going to make a post.

Actually, almost the opposite is true, Stafford loans to students top out at $31,000 for 4 years. The huge debts ARE private loans which can go up to $200,000 and carry much higher interest.

As for ability to pay, who can tell when you'r in college? My kids with no credit history at all were given private loans up the the full cost of college. (We managed to avoid taking them.)

Giving students government loans is literally the worst idea imaginable.

1) Government student loans are non-dischargeable
2) Government loans are granted regardless of the ability to pay it back

The two above are a veritable recipe for indentured servitude. Higher education should either be free or financed through private loans. No banker would give the average student a loan to study anything that wasn't marketable.

Dr. Krugman & Mr. Betz:
What has mystified me for the past 25 years or more is the mindless proclivity demonstrated by almost 50 percent of the electorate to repeatedly vote against their own best interest and the stability of the nation year after year, election after election.
Now, they grouse that the downturn is giving them a hard time as they approach or just enter retirement, however they continue like mindless robots to vote for the same losing rhetoric like it is their new religion.
Finding out that from Inauguration Day, the GOP in Congress charged into battle by creating an impregnable wall against any agreements for the good of the nation tells me they are more than rank hypocrites -- they are traitors conspiring to bring down the country for personal gain.
Despite that, President Obama and his administration have done well, but think of how much better off we would be had we had some cooperation.
Now that the election is near, we are uncovering their real agenda -- they are out to bring down women (and "put them in their place", "little" women that we are), while plotting to deny 75 to 80 percent of college students the completion of their education due to the exorbitant debt they are amassing.
With soaring fees, it is doubtful today's students could pay off their educational debt prior to retirement.
That means many will likely never be able to retire in peace.
The question is:
Are there enough voters left able to actually reason?
Or care?

We need to be as blunt as possible in attacking the craziness on the right.

The Karl Rove folks are essentially saying, "Them that have get. Them that don't won't.

They want a sink-or-swim society. They want a lot of people to vote against their economic self-interest. A few will make out swimmingly. Many won't.

Continue to be as plain as possible, PK.
